verses.text: In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, Abijam became king over Judah.
verses.comment: The Hebrew name here is 'Abijam,' though some texts use 'Abijah'.

verses.text: He reigned three years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Maacah, the daughter of Abishalom.
verses.comment: Maacah is noted as both daughter and granddaughter of Abishalom in different texts.

verses.text: He walked in all the sins his father did before him, and his heart was not fully devoted to Yahweh his God, as was the heart of David his father.
verses.comment: ‘Fully devoted’ was written as ‘perfect’ in older translations.

verses.text: But for David’s sake, Yahweh his God gave him a lamp in Jerusalem, raising up his son after him and establishing Jerusalem.
verses.comment: ‘Lamp’ means a continual dynasty or posterity.

verses.text: Because David did what was right in Yahweh’s eyes and did not turn aside from anything he commanded him all the days of his life, except in the matter of Uriah the Hittite.
verses.comment: Explicit reference to David’s sin regarding Uriah.

verses.text: There was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam all the days of his life.
verses.comment: Refers to ongoing conflict between Judah and Israel.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Abijam, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah? There was war between Abijam and Jeroboam.
verses.comment: Reference to other historical sources.

verses.text: Abijam slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the city of David. Asa his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: Standard expression for death and succession.

verses.text: In the twentieth year of Jeroboam, king of Israel, Asa began to reign over Judah.
verses.comment: Synchronizes the reigns of kings in both kingdoms.

verses.text: He reigned forty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Maacah, the daughter of Abishalom.
verses.comment: Possible discrepancy: Maacah as either mother or grandmother.

verses.text: Asa did what was right in Yahweh’s eyes, as David his father did.
verses.comment: ‘As David’ emphasizes righteousness modeled after David.

verses.text: He removed the male shrine prostitutes from the land and put away all the idols that his fathers had made.
verses.comment: ‘Male shrine prostitutes’ refers to cultic sexual practices.

verses.text: He also removed Maacah his mother from being queen mother because she had made an abominable image for Asherah. Asa cut down her abominable image and burned it at the Kidron Valley.
verses.comment: ‘Abominable image’ (Hebrew: ‘Miphletzet’) means a disgusting idol.

verses.text: But the high places were not removed. Nevertheless, Asa’s heart was fully devoted to Yahweh all his days.
verses.comment: High places were unauthorized worship sites contrary to the Law.

verses.text: He brought into the house of Yahweh the things that his father had dedicated, and that he himself had dedicated, silver, gold, and vessels.
verses.comment: Dedication of treasures to the Temple.

verses.text: There was war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel all their days.
verses.comment: Ongoing border conflict between Judah and Israel.

verses.text: Baasha king of Israel went up against Judah and built Ramah, so he might not let anyone go out or come in to Asa king of Judah.
verses.comment: Ramah was a strategic location north of Jerusalem.

verses.text: Then Asa took all the silver and gold that was left in the treasuries of Yahweh’s house and the treasures of the king’s house, and gave them into the hand of his servants; and King Asa sent them to Ben-hadad son of Tabrimmon, son of Hezion, king of Syria, who lived in Damascus, saying:
verses.comment: Ben-hadad was the ruling Syrian king in Damascus.

verses.text: Let there be a covenant between me and you, as there was between my father and your father. I am sending you a gift of silver and gold. Go, break your covenant with Baasha king of Israel, so that he may withdraw from me.
verses.comment: Asa seeks to enlist Syria against Israel by diplomatic means.

verses.text: Ben-hadad listened to King Asa and sent the commanders of his armies against the cities of Israel. They attacked Ijon, Dan, Abel-beth-maacah, and all Kinneroth, with all the land of Naphtali.
verses.comment: Cities listed are northern towns within the tribe of Naphtali.

verses.text: When Baasha heard of it, he stopped building Ramah and remained in Tirzah.
verses.comment: Tirzah served as Baasha’s capital.

verses.text: Then King Asa made a proclamation to all Judah—none was exempt. They carried away the stones of Ramah and its timber, which Baasha had used for building. With these, King Asa built Geba of Benjamin and Mizpah.
verses.comment: Geba and Mizpah are strategic border towns.

verses.text: Now the rest of all the acts of Asa, all his might, and all that he did, and the cities he built, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah? But in his old age, he was diseased in his feet.
verses.comment: ‘Diseased in his feet’ possibly refers to a severe infection or gout.

verses.text: Asa slept with his fathers and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David his father. Jehoshaphat his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: Standard formula for royal succession.

verses.text: Nadab, the son of Jeroboam, became king over Israel in the second year of Asa king of Judah, and reigned over Israel two years.
verses.comment: Return to the northern kings (Israel).

verses.text: He did what was evil in Yahweh’s eyes and walked in the way of his father, and in his sin that he made Israel commit.
verses.comment: Summary judgment of Nadab’s reign.

verses.text: Baasha son of Ahijah, from the tribe of Issachar, conspired against him, and struck him down at Gibbethon, which belonged to the Philistines, while Nadab and all Israel were besieging Gibbethon.
verses.comment: Assassination occurred during military campaign.

verses.text: Baasha killed Nadab in the third year of Asa king of Judah and became king in his place.
verses.comment: Chronological note of Nadab’s death and succession by Baasha.

verses.text: As soon as he became king, he struck down all the house of Jeroboam. He did not leave any breathing person belonging to Jeroboam, until he had destroyed them, according to the word of Yahweh which he spoke by his servant Ahijah the Shilonite.
verses.comment: Fulfillment of prophetic judgment on Jeroboam’s house.

verses.text: Because of the sins which Jeroboam committed and made Israel commit, by which he provoked Yahweh, the God of Israel, to anger.
verses.comment: Direct link between sin and divine punishment.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Nadab, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
verses.comment: Repeated reference to lost historical records.

verses.text: There was war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel all their days.
verses.comment: Restates persistent border conflict.

verses.text: In the third year of Asa king of Judah, Baasha son of Ahijah became king over all Israel at Tirzah, and he reigned twenty-four years.
verses.comment: Note on Baasha’s long reign.

verses.text: He did what was evil in Yahweh’s eyes and walked in the way of Jeroboam, and in his sin by which he made Israel sin.
verses.comment: Echoes the pattern of sin established by Jeroboam.
